Ben is a big boy. He likes to help his dad work. His dad has a belt with many tools. Ben wants to use the tools too.
"Can I have the hammer, dad?" Ben asks.
"Sorry, Ben, this hammer is too heavy for you. You can have this screwdriver. It is smaller and lighter," dad says.
Ben takes the screwdriver and tries to fix a chair. He turns the screwdriver left and right. He makes a loud noise. He thinks it is fun.
But soon he gets bored. The chair is still broken. The screwdriver is not enough. He wants to use the hammer, the saw, the drill, and the other tools on dad's belt.
"Dad, can I have another tool? The screwdriver is boring," Ben says.
"Not now, Ben. I need all the tools to finish the work. Maybe later you can have another tool. But you have to be careful. The tools are sharp and dangerous. They can hurt you if you don't use them right," dad says.
Ben is sad. He wants to work like dad. He wants to use all the tools. He thinks dad's belt is the best thing ever. He waits for dad to finish the work. He hopes dad will let him have another tool. He hopes dad will teach him how to use them. He hopes dad will be proud of him.
<|endoftext|>

Ben and Lily were playing with blocks. They liked to build towers and houses and cars. But sometimes they wanted the same blocks and they got mad.
One day, Ben saw a big red block that he wanted. He reached for it, but Lily grabbed it first. She said, "This is mine! I saw it first!" Ben felt angry. He wanted the red block. He pushed Lily and made her drop the block. Lily felt sad. She cried and said, "That was not nice! You hurt me!"
Ben felt sorry. He did not mean to hurt Lily. He just wanted the red block. He said, "I'm sorry, Lily. I was wrong. Can I have the red block, please?" Lily looked at Ben. She saw that he was sorry. She said, "OK, Ben. You can have the red block. But you have to be gentle. The block is rough and it can scratch you."
Ben smiled. He said, "Thank you, Lily. You are a good friend. I forgive you for taking the red block." Lily smiled too. She said, "You're welcome, Ben. I forgive you for pushing me." They hugged and said, "We are sorry. We are friends."
They played with the blocks again. They shared the red block and the other blocks. They built a big castle and a dragon and a princess. They had fun and they were happy.
<|endoftext|>

Tom was a boy who liked to play with his toy cars. He had many cars of different colors and sizes. He liked to make them zoom and crash on the floor. One day, he found a rat in his room. The rat was small and gray, with a long tail and sharp teeth. Tom was nervous. He did not like rats. He thought they were dirty and scary.
He ran to his mom and said, "Mom, there is a rat in my room! Help me!" His mom came with him and saw the rat. She was not nervous. She was kind. She said, "Tom, this is not a rat. This is a mouse. A mouse is a small animal that likes to eat cheese and seeds. He is not dirty or scary. He is just looking for a home."
Tom looked at the mouse. He saw that he had small ears and a cute nose. He saw that he was not mean or angry. He was just scared and hungry. Tom felt sorry for the mouse. He said, "Mom, can we keep the mouse? Can we give him a name and a cage and some food?" His mom smiled and said, "Yes, Tom, we can. But you have to take good care of him. You have to raise him like a pet. You have to feed him and clean him and play with him. Can you do that?"
Tom nodded and said, "Yes, Mom, I can. I will raise him like a pet. I will name him Max. He will be my friend." He picked up the mouse gently and put him in a cage. He gave him some cheese and some seeds. He watched him nibble and squeak. He felt happy. He learned that rats and mice are not the same. He learned that animals are not bad or good. They are just different. He learned that being kind and brave is better than being nervous and mean. He learned to love Max the mouse.
<|endoftext|>

Lily and Ben are twins. They like to play hide and seek. Lily is good at hiding. Ben is good at seeking. One day, they play in the kitchen. Lily hides behind the big fridge. Ben counts to ten.
"Ready or not, here I come!" Ben says. He looks under the table. He looks in the cupboards. He looks behind the chairs. He cannot find Lily. He thinks she is very good at hiding.
He sees a bottle on the counter. It is red and shiny. It has a funny word on it. It says "wine". Ben does not know what wine is. He thinks it is juice. He wants to drink some. He climbs on a stool. He reaches for the bottle.
Lily sees Ben from behind the fridge. She sees him touch the bottle. She knows wine is not for kids. She knows wine is for grown-ups. She knows wine is yucky. She wants to stop Ben. She jumps out from behind the fridge.
"Ben, no!" she shouts. "That is not juice! That is wine!"
Ben is surprised. He drops the bottle. It breaks on the floor. It makes a loud noise. It makes a big mess. It makes red spots everywhere.
Lily and Ben are scared. They hear Mom and Dad come in. They see them look at the broken bottle. They see them look at the red spots. They see them look at Lily and Ben.
"What happened here?" Mom asks.
Lily and Ben do not know what to say. They feel bad. They feel silly. They peek at each other. They say sorry. Mom and Dad are not happy. They are not angry. They are glad Lily and Ben are safe. They hug them. They clean up the mess. They tell them wine is not for kids. They tell them to be careful. They tell them to have fun. They tell them they love them. Lily and Ben love them too. They say thank you. They say they will not touch wine again. They say they will play nice. They say they will find a better place to hide.
<|endoftext|>

Ben and Mia liked to play near the park. The park had a big pond with ducks and fish. The park also had a rail that stopped people from falling into the pond. Ben and Mia's mom always told them to stay away from the rail and not to climb on it.
One day, Ben and Mia saw some older kids climbing on the rail. They looked like they were having fun. Ben wanted to join them, but Mia was scared. She said, "Mom said no. It is not safe. We can fall and get hurt."
Ben said, "Mom is not here. She will not know. I want to try. It looks easy." He ran to the rail and started to climb on it. Mia followed him and said, "Please, Ben, come back. It is not good. You are not listening."
But Ben did not listen. He climbed higher and higher on the rail. He felt brave and happy. He said, "Look at me, Mia. I am so high. I can see everything."
Mia said, "Ben, be careful. The rail is not strong. It can break. You can fall."
But Ben did not hear her. He was too busy looking around. He did not see that the rail was old and rusty. He did not see that it was shaking and cracking. He did not see that it was about to snap.
Suddenly, the rail broke. Ben screamed and fell into the pond. He splashed and sank. He was scared and cold. He could not swim. He could not breathe.
Mia saw what happened. She was calm and smart. She ran to the older kids and asked for help. They called for a grown-up. The grown-up came and jumped into the pond. He grabbed Ben and pulled him out. He gave him a towel and checked if he was okay.
Ben was wet and shivering. He was sorry and sad. He said, "Thank you, sir. Thank you, Mia. I was wrong. I should have listened to mom. I should have listened to you. I was not safe. I was not good."
Mia hugged him and said, "It is okay, Ben. I am glad you are okay. I love you. But next time, please do not climb on the rail. It is not fun. It is dangerous."
Ben nodded and said, "I promise, Mia. I learned my lesson. I will not do it again. I will be good."
The moral of the story is: Do not do things that are not permitted. They can be harmful and hurtful. Listen to your mom and your sister. They know what is best for you. Be calm and smart. Ask for help when you need it.
<|endoftext|>

Lily and Tom are brother and sister. They live in a big house with Mom and Dad. Lily and Tom like to play together. They have many toys and books and games.
One night, Mom and Dad say they have to go out. They say they will be back soon. They say Lily and Tom have to stay with Grandma. Grandma is nice, but she is old and slow. She does not know how to play with Lily and Tom.
Lily and Tom say goodbye to Mom and Dad. They hug and kiss them. They say they love them. They say they will be good. Mom and Dad say they love them too. They say they will be back soon. They say they will miss them.
Grandma makes dinner for Lily and Tom. She makes soup and bread and cheese. Lily and Tom eat a little, but they are not hungry. They miss Mom and Dad. They want to play with them.
After dinner, Grandma says it is time for bed. She says they have to brush their teeth and put on their pajamas. Lily and Tom do what Grandma says, but they are not sleepy. They miss Mom and Dad. They want to hug and kiss them.
Grandma tucks them in their beds. She says goodnight and turns off the light. She says she will be in the next room if they need her. Lily and Tom say goodnight, but they are not happy. They miss Mom and Dad. They want to hear their voices.
Lily and Tom lie in their beds. They look at the dark window. They see the stars and the moon. They feel cold and lonely. They miss Mom and Dad. They want to see their faces.
Lily whispers to Tom. She says, "Tom, are you awake?"
Tom whispers back. He says, "Yes, Lily, I am awake."
Lily says, "Tom, I miss Mom and Dad. Do you miss them too?"
Tom says, "Yes, Lily, I miss them too. I wish they were here."
Lily says, "Tom, can I come to your bed? I am cold and scared."
Tom says, "Yes, Lily, you can come to my bed. I am cold and scared too."
Lily gets out of her bed. She walks to Tom's bed. She climbs in with him. They cuddle and hold each other. They feel warm and safe. They miss Mom and Dad, but they have each other. They close their eyes and fall asleep.
<|endoftext|>

Sara and Ben are friends. They like to play together. One day, they go to the town with Sara's mom. The town is lively. There are many people and cars and shops.
"Look, Ben, there is a toy store!" Sara says. She points to a window with dolls and cars and balls. "Can we go inside, mom?"
"Okay, but only for a little while. We have to finish our shopping soon," Sara's mom says. She holds their hands and leads them to the store.
Sara and Ben are happy. They see many toys they like. Sara picks up a doll with a pink dress. Ben picks up a car with a blue siren. They show each other their toys.
"These are nice, but we can't buy them today. Maybe another time," Sara's mom says. She puts the toys back on the shelf. "Come on, we have to go. Say bye to the toys."
"Bye, toys. See you later," Sara and Ben say. They wave to the toys and follow Sara's mom. They leave the store and walk to the bus stop. They wait for the bus to take them home.
They had a fun day in the town. They saw many things and played with toys. They are tired but happy. They hug each other and say, "You are my best friend."
<|endoftext|>

Nina liked to look at the stars at night. She wondered how they could shine so bright and far away. She asked her mom, "Mom, why do the stars shine?"
Mom smiled and hugged Nina. She said, "The stars shine because they are very hot and big. They are like big balls of fire in the sky. They give us light and make the night beautiful."
Nina nodded and said, "I like the stars. They are pretty and unique. They are not like anything else."
Mom said, "That's true, Nina. The stars are unique, just like you. You are also pretty and unique. You have your own body, your own mind, and your own heart. No one else is like you. You are special and I love you."
Nina felt happy and warm. She said, "I love you too, Mom. And I love the stars. Can we look at them some more?"
Mom said, "Of course, Nina. Let's look at them together and make some wishes. Maybe they will come true."
Nina and Mom looked at the stars and wished for many things. They felt close and cozy. They thanked the stars for shining and making them happy.
<|endoftext|>

Tom and Lily were twins who liked to play together. They had many toys, but their favorite was a big box of crayons. They liked to draw and color on paper, on the wall, and sometimes on each other.
One day, they decided to try something new. They took a pair of scissors from their mom's desk and started to cut their crayons. They wanted to see what was inside them. They cut the red crayon, the blue crayon, the yellow crayon, and all the other colors. They were surprised to discover that all the crayons had the same thing inside: a white stick.
"Look, Lily, all the crayons are the same inside!" Tom said.
"That's weird, Tom, they look so different outside!" Lily said.
They cut more and more crayons, until they had a pile of white sticks and colorful pieces. They tried to put them back together, but they could not. They had broken their crayons.
Mom came into the room and saw the mess. She was not happy. She scolded Tom and Lily for cutting their crayons and wasting them. She told them to clean up and to never use scissors without asking. She also told them that they should not judge things by their outside, but by their inside.
Tom and Lily felt sorry for what they had done. They apologized to Mom and to their crayons. They learned that cutting things was not fun, and that different things could have the same value. They promised to be more careful and respectful with their toys and with each other.
<|endoftext|>

Lily liked to help her mom in the kitchen. She wanted to work like a big girl. She saw her mom cut some carrots with a knife. Lily asked, "Can I cut too?"
Mom smiled and said, "No, Lily, cutting is not for little hands. You can use a fork to poke the carrots. That is your work."
Lily took a fork and poked the carrots. She liked the sound they made. She poked and poked until all the carrots were on a plate. She was very patient and careful.
Mom said, "Good job, Lily! You worked very well. Now we can cook the carrots for dinner. Do you want to stir them in the pot?"
Lily nodded and said, "Yes, please!" She put down her fork and climbed on a stool. Mom gave her a wooden spoon and showed her how to stir. Lily stirred and stirred until the carrots were soft and yummy.
Mom said, "You are a great helper, Lily. I am proud of you. Now we can eat the carrots. Do you want some?"
Lily said, "Yes, please! I love carrots. They are my favorite." She took her fork and ate some carrots. She shared them with her mom. They were both happy and full.
<|endoftext|>

One day, a boy named Tom went to the zoo with his mom and dad. He liked to see all the animals, but his favorite was the big gorilla. He wanted to talk to the gorilla and be his friend.
He went close to the glass and said, "Hello, gorilla. You are so big and strong. Can I play with you?"
The gorilla looked at Tom and made a funny sound. He showed his teeth and beat his chest. He wanted to show Tom that he was the boss.
Tom felt scared and ran back to his mom and dad. He said, "The gorilla is mean and loud. He does not want to play with me."
His mom and dad hugged him and said, "Don't be sad, Tom. The gorilla is not mean. He is just humble. He does not like to show off or brag. He is happy with what he has. He does not need to play with you. He has his own friends and family in the zoo."
Tom felt better and said, "I understand, mom and dad. The gorilla is humble and happy. I am humble and happy too. I have you and my friends and toys. Maybe next time, the gorilla will smile at me."
<|endoftext|>

Tom and Lily were friends. They liked to play in the park. One day, they found a basket under a tree. The basket had many things inside. Some things were soft, some things were hard, some things were shiny, some things were dull.
"Wow, look at this basket!" Tom said. "It has so many different things. Can we play with them?"
"Sure, let's play with them," Lily said. "But we have to share. You can have one thing, and I can have one thing. Then we can swap."
Tom and Lily picked one thing each from the basket. Tom picked a ball. It was soft and red. Lily picked a ring. It was hard and shiny. They played with their things for a while. Then they wanted to swap.
"Can I have your ring?" Tom asked. "It is shiny and pretty. I want to see how it looks on my finger."
"OK, you can have my ring," Lily said. "But can I have your ball? It is soft and bouncy. I want to see how high it can go."
Tom and Lily swapped their things. But they were not happy. Tom's finger was too big for the ring. It hurt and it got stuck. Lily's ball was too small for her hand. It slipped and it rolled away.
"Ow, ow, ow!" Tom cried. "The ring is too tight. It won't come off. Help me, Lily!"
"Oh no, oh no, oh no!" Lily cried. "The ball is too fast. It went into the road. Help me, Tom!"
Tom and Lily ran to each other. They tried to help each other. But they could not. The ring was too hard to pull. The ball was too far to catch. They were scared and sad.
Then they heard a voice. It was a woman. She came from the tree. She had a hat and a coat. She looked kind and wise.
"Hello, children," she said. "I see you found my basket. It has many different things. But they are not for playing. They are for learning. Each thing has a story and a lesson. Do you want to hear them?"
Tom and Lily nodded. They wanted to hear the stories and the lessons. They wanted to get the ring off and the ball back. They wanted to be happy again.
The woman smiled. She took the ring from Tom's finger. She took the ball from the road. She put them back in the basket. Then she sat down with Tom and Lily. She began to talk. She told them stories and lessons. She told them about the different things in the basket. She told them how to be kind, curious, brave, and wise. Tom and Lily listened. They learned. They thanked the woman. They hugged each other. They were happy again.
<|endoftext|>

Ben liked to play with his mom's things. He liked to look at her shiny rings, her soft scarves, and her big calendar. The calendar had many pictures of animals and flowers. Ben wanted to see them better, so he took the calendar to his room.
He put the calendar on his bed and opened it. He saw a picture of a lion with a big mane. He touched the lion and said, "Roar!" He saw a picture of a rose with many petals. He smelled the rose and said, "Ah!" He saw a picture of a whale with a big tail. He splashed the whale and said, "Splash!"
But then he saw a picture of a button with a red light. He did not know what it was, but it looked attractive. He pressed the button and said, "Beep!" Suddenly, he felt a strange feeling. He looked at his hands and feet. They were getting smaller and smaller. He was shrinking!
He tried to scream, but his voice was too tiny. He tried to run, but his legs were too short. He tried to climb, but his arms were too weak. He was trapped on the bed, with the big calendar. He saw the lion, the rose, and the whale. They looked scary and hungry. They moved closer and closer to him. He closed his eyes and hoped it was a bad dream. But it was not. It was the end.
<|endoftext|>

Sara and Tom are twins. They like to play outside. But today the weather is cold and rainy. Mom says they have to wear coats and boots.
"I don't want to wear this coat!" Sara says. "It is ugly and itchy. I want to wear my pink dress."
"You can't wear your dress, Sara," Tom says. "It is too wet and muddy. You will get sick and dirty. And your dress is expensive. Mom will be mad."
"I don't care," Sara says. "I want to look pretty. You are silly and boring. You always wear the same coat and boots."
Sara runs to her room and puts on her dress. She sneaks out of the door and goes to the yard. She jumps in a puddle and laughs.
Tom follows her and sees her dress. He is shocked and angry. He runs to her and tries to pull her back.
"Stop, Sara, stop!" he says. "You are ruining your dress. Come inside. Mom will be here soon."
"Leave me alone, Tom!" Sara says. "You are mean and rude. I don't want to play with you. Go away."
They start to fight and push each other. They fall in the mud and get wet and dirty. They cry and scream.
Mom comes home and sees them. She is shocked and angry. She takes them inside and scolds them.
"What have you done, Sara and Tom?" she says. "You are both in trouble. You have to clean up and say sorry. And Sara, your dress is expensive. You have to pay for it with your allowance."
Sara and Tom feel bad and ashamed. They apologize to Mom and to each other. They hug and make up. They promise to listen to Mom and to wear the right clothes for the weather.
<|endoftext|>

Tom and Anna liked to play music with their toys. Tom had a drum and Anna had a flute. They made sounds with their toys and tried to follow a rhythm. A rhythm is when you make sounds that go together and have a pattern.
One day, they decided to play music outside in the garden. They found a nice spot under a big tree and started to play. Tom banged his drum and Anna blew her flute. They had fun making their own rhythm.
But then, a big bird came and landed on the tree. The bird was very bossy. It did not like the music that Tom and Anna made. It started to squawk and screech very loudly. It wanted to stop them from playing.
"Shoo, shoo, go away!" Tom said to the bird. "We are playing music, you are making noise!"
"No, no, you go away!" the bird said to Tom. "You are making noise, I am singing!"
The bird and Tom argued and shouted. Anna did not like the noise. She wanted to play music with Tom. She had an idea. She took her flute and started to play a different rhythm. A rhythm that sounded like the bird's squawks and screeches.
The bird heard Anna's flute and stopped shouting. It was surprised and curious. It listened to Anna's rhythm and tried to copy it. It squawked and screeched along with Anna's flute.
Tom heard Anna's flute and the bird's squawks. He was surprised and curious too. He stopped banging his drum and listened to Anna's rhythm. He liked it. He took his drum and started to play a different rhythm. A rhythm that matched Anna's flute and the bird's squawks.
Anna, Tom and the bird played music together. They made a new rhythm. A rhythm that spread through the garden and made them happy. They were not bossy anymore. They were friends.
<|endoftext|>

Tim and Sam were brothers who liked to play with their toys. One day, they found a big box of stickers in their room. They were very happy and wanted to stick them everywhere.
"Look, Sam, I have a sticker of a lion. I will put it on the wall," Tim said.
"No, Tim, you can't do that. Mom will be mad. She said the wall is not for stickers. Only paper is for stickers," Sam said.
But Tim did not listen. He spread the stickers all over the wall, the door, the window, and the bed. He thought it looked very pretty.
"Tim, stop it! You are making a mess. Mom will see and she will put us in jail," Sam said.
"Jail? What is jail?" Tim asked.
"Jail is a bad place where you can't play or have fun. You have to stay in a small room with bars and no toys. Mom will send us there if we are naughty," Sam said.
Tim was scared. He did not want to go to jail. He wanted to play and have fun. He looked at the wall and saw how many stickers he had used. He felt sorry.
"Sam, I'm sorry. I did not know. How can we fix it?" Tim asked.
Sam thought for a moment. He had an idea.
"Maybe we can peel off the stickers and put them back in the box. Then we can clean the wall with a cloth and some water. Maybe Mom will not notice," Sam said.
Tim and Sam worked together to remove the stickers and clean the wall. It was hard work, but they did it. They put the box of stickers away and hoped Mom would not find out.
When Mom came home, she did not see anything wrong. She hugged Tim and Sam and said she was glad they had a good day. Tim and Sam smiled and hugged her back. They were glad too. They decided to be more careful with their stickers next time.
<|endoftext|>

Ben was hungry. He wanted toast for breakfast. He asked his mom, "Can I have toast, please?"
Mom said, "Yes, you can. But first, you have to brush your teeth and wash your face. Then you can have toast."
Ben nodded. He went to the bathroom. He brushed his teeth and washed his face. He was a good boy.
But when he came back to the kitchen, he saw something strange. His toast was gone. There was only a plate with some crumbs. He looked around. He saw a trail of crumbs on the floor. He followed the trail. He wondered, "Who took my toast?"
He wandered into the living room. He saw his dog, Spot, on the couch. Spot had something in his mouth. It was Ben's toast. Spot was chewing it. It looked tough. Ben was angry. He said, "Spot, you bad dog! You took my toast! That was mine!"
Spot looked at Ben. He wagged his tail. He dropped the toast. He licked Ben's face. He wanted to play. He did not know he did something wrong.
Ben was still hungry. He did not want the toast anymore. It was dirty and tough. He went back to the kitchen. He asked his mom, "Can I have something else, please?"
Mom said, "Of course, you can. How about some cereal and milk?"
Ben said, "Yes, please. That sounds good."
Mom smiled. She gave Ben some cereal and milk. She said, "Next time, don't leave your toast on the table. Spot likes toast, too. He is a sneaky dog."
Ben said, "I know. I will be careful. I love Spot, but he is a naughty dog."
Mom said, "I love Spot, too. But he needs to learn some manners."
They laughed. They ate their breakfast. They were happy.
<|endoftext|>

Lily and Sam are friends. They like to play outside. But today is very hot. The sun is bright and the air is warm.
"Let's go to the park," Sam says. "We can run and slide and swing."
Lily shakes her head. "No, Sam. It is too hot. We will get tired and thirsty. And we will sweat a lot."
Sam frowns. "But I want to play. I don't like to stay inside. It is boring."
Lily thinks for a moment. She has an idea. "I know what we can do. We can play dress-up. We can wear different clothes and pretend to be someone else. It will be fun."
Sam smiles. "That sounds good. What clothes do you have?"
Lily takes Sam to her room. She opens her closet. She has many clothes. She has dresses and skirts and shirts and pants and hats and shoes. She has clothes for cold days and clothes for hot days.
"Look, Sam. We can wear these clothes. They are for hot days. They are light and thin and cool. They will not make us sweat. I recommend these clothes."
Sam nods. He likes Lily's clothes. He picks a shirt with stripes and a hat with a star. Lily picks a dress with flowers and a necklace with beads. They put on the clothes. They look at each other. They laugh.
"You look funny, Sam. You look like a pirate."
"You look pretty, Lily. You look like a princess."
They go to the living room. They pretend to be a pirate and a princess. They have a lot of fun. They forget about the heat. They are happy.
<|endoftext|>

Tom and Lily love to play soccer. They kick the ball to each other in the park. They wear red shirts and blue shorts. They are on the same team.
One day, they go to a big stadium with their mom and dad. They see many people and many flags. They hear loud noises and music. They are very excited. They want to see their favorite players.
But when the game starts, something bad happens. The other team scores many goals. Their team does not score any. Tom and Lily are sad. They do not like to see their team lose. They do not cheer or clap. They sit quietly and look down.
Mom and dad see that Tom and Lily are sad. They hug them and say, "It's okay. Sometimes you win, sometimes you lose. The important thing is to have fun and try your best. You are still our champions."
Tom and Lily look at mom and dad. They see that they are smiling. They feel a little better. They smile back and say, "Thank you. We love you. Can we play soccer when we go home?"
Mom and dad nod and say, "Of course. You can play soccer anytime you want. You are very good at it. Maybe one day you will play in a big stadium too."
Tom and Lily smile more and hug mom and dad. They forget about the game and think about playing soccer. They are happy again.
<|endoftext|>

Sara and Ben were playing with their blocks in the garden. They liked to build towers and bridges and houses with the blocks. They had many colors and shapes of blocks.
But then a big dog came running into the garden. The dog was nosy and wanted to see what the children were doing. He barked and wagged his tail and ran around the blocks.
"Go away, dog!" Sara said. "You are not our friend. You are messing up our blocks!"
But the dog did not listen. He jumped on the blocks and knocked them down. He scattered the blocks all over the ground. He made a big mess.
"Stop, dog!" Ben said. "You are being bad. You are ruining our fun!"
But the dog did not stop. He picked up some blocks in his mouth and ran away with them. He thought the blocks were toys for him.
Sara and Ben were very sad and angry. They cried and shouted at the dog. They wanted their blocks back. They did not like the nosy dog.
<|endoftext|>

Lily liked to play with her phone. It was a toy phone, but it looked like a real one. She could press the buttons and hear different sounds. Sometimes she pretended to talk to her friends or her family.
One day, she was playing with her phone in her room, when she heard a real phone ring in the living room. She ran to see who it was. She saw her mom pick up the phone and say hello.
"Hi, mom, it's me, your aunt," a voice said from the phone. Lily recognized the voice. It was her aunt Mia, who lived far away. Lily loved her aunt Mia. She was very nice and intelligent. She knew many things and told Lily stories.
Lily wanted to talk to her aunt Mia too. She grabbed her toy phone and ran to her mom. She held her phone to her ear and said, "Hi, aunt Mia, it's me, Lily!"
Her mom smiled and handed her the real phone. "Here, Lily, you can talk to your aunt Mia for a while. She wants to hear how you are doing."
Lily was very happy. She took the phone and said, "Hi, aunt Mia, I miss you. How are you? I have a new toy phone. It makes sounds. Do you want to hear?"
She pressed a button and made her toy phone beep. She heard her aunt Mia laugh on the other end.
"I hear you, Lily. Your toy phone is very cool. You are very clever. I miss you too. I have a surprise for you. Do you want to know what it is?"
Lily nodded, even though her aunt Mia could not see her. She said, "Yes, please. Tell me. What is it?"
Her aunt Mia said, "I am coming to visit you soon. I have a plane ticket. I will be there in two weeks. Are you excited?"
Lily gasped. She was very excited. She said, "Yes, yes, yes! I can't wait to see you. We will have so much fun. Thank you, aunt Mia. I love you."
She heard her aunt Mia say, "I love you too, Lily. I will see you soon. Bye for now."
Lily said, "Bye, aunt Mia." She gave the phone back to her mom and hugged her. She said, "Mom, did you hear? Aunt Mia is coming. She has a plane ticket. She is very intelligent. She knows how to fly."
Her mom hugged her back and said, "Yes, I heard. Aunt Mia is coming. She is very intelligent. She knows how to fly. And she loves you very much. Just like I do."
<|endoftext|>

Anna and Ben like to play in the park. They see a big truck with many branches on it. The truck is loud and strong. The truck driver is nice. He says, "Hello, kids. Do you want to help me load the branches?"
Anna and Ben nod and smile. They run to the truck and pick up some branches. The branches are brown and green. Some are long and some are short. Some are hard and some are soft. Anna and Ben carry the branches to the truck and put them on it. They work hard and have fun.
The truck driver says, "Thank you, kids. You are very helpful. Do you want a ride in the truck?" Anna and Ben say, "Yes, please!" They climb into the truck and sit next to the driver. The driver starts the truck and drives away. The truck makes a big noise. Anna and Ben wave to the park and the trees. They feel happy and proud. They helped to load the branches.

Lily and Ben are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big balloon. It is red and shiny. It has a price tag on it. It says "one dollar".
"Wow, look at the balloon!" Lily says. "I want it!"
"Me too!" Ben says. "But we have no money."
They look at the balloon. They feel sad.
A lady walks by. She sees Lily and Ben. She smiles at them.
"Hello, kids. Do you like the balloon?" she asks.
"Yes, we do!" Lily and Ben say.
"Well, I have an extra dollar. Do you want to buy the balloon?" she asks.
Lily and Ben are surprised. They nod their heads.
"Thank you, lady!" they say.
The lady gives them the dollar. They give it to the man who sells the balloon. He gives them the balloon.
Lily and Ben are happy. They hold the balloon together. They jump and laugh.
"Thank you, thank you, thank you!" they say to the lady.
"You're welcome, kids. Enjoy the balloon. But be careful, don't let it fly away!" she says.
She waves at them and walks away.
Lily and Ben look at each other. They smile.
"You are my best friend!" Lily says.
"You are my best friend too!" Ben says.
They kiss each other on the cheek. They are glad. They have a balloon and a friend.

Anna and Ben were friends who liked to play by the river. They had a raft that they made from wood and rope. They took turns to paddle the raft and pretend they were explorers.
One day, they saw a swan swimming in the water. It was white and graceful, with a long neck and a big beak. Anna and Ben wanted to get closer to the swan, so they paddled the raft towards it.
"Hello, swan," Anna said. "You are very pretty. Can we be your friends?"
The swan looked at them and nodded. It swam next to the raft and let Anna and Ben touch its feathers.
"Thank you, swan," Ben said. "You are very kind. Can we lend you our raft? You can sit on it and rest."
The swan smiled and climbed on the raft. It flapped its wings and made a soft sound. Anna and Ben were happy to share their raft with the swan. They paddled the raft along the river and enjoyed the sunny day.

Tom and Lily wanted to play with the big steel train that was in the toy store. They asked their mom if they could buy it, but she said no. She said it was too expensive and they had enough toys at home.
"But mom, we love the steel train! It is so shiny and fast and loud!" Tom said.
"Please, mom, can we just look at it for a little while?" Lily said.
Mom sighed. She said they could look at it for five minutes, but then they had to go home. She had to cook dinner and do other things.
Tom and Lily ran to the steel train and touched it with their hands. They pretended they were the drivers and the passengers. They made train noises and laughed.
Mom looked at her watch. She said it was time to go. She called Tom and Lily, but they did not listen. They wanted to play more.
Mom was angry. She walked to the steel train and grabbed Tom and Lily by their arms. She said they were naughty and they had to leave now.
Tom and Lily were sad. They did not want to leave the steel train. They had an idea. They said they were sorry and they hugged mom. They said they loved her and they would be good.
Mom smiled. She said they were clever and sweet. She said she would give them one more minute to play with the steel train.
Tom and Lily were happy. They thanked mom and played with the steel train again. They did not know they had delayed mom and made her late. They only knew they had fun.

Lily and Ben are friends. They like to play games. Today they play a game with cards. The cards have pictures of animals.
Lily and Ben sit on the floor. They take turns to pick a card and show it to the other. They have to say the name of the animal and make its sound.
Lily picks a card with a cat. She shows it to Ben and says, "Cat. Meow, meow." Ben nods and smiles.
Ben picks a card with a dog. He shows it to Lily and says, "Dog. Woof, woof." Lily nods and smiles.
They keep playing until they have no more cards. They count how many cards they have. Lily has six cards. Ben has five cards.
Lily says, "I have more cards. I win!"
Ben says, "No, you don't. It's a tie. We both win!"
Lily thinks for a moment. She says, "Okay, we both win. This game is easy and fun. Do you want to play again?"
Ben says, "Yes, I do. You are a good player. And a good friend."
Lily and Ben hug and laugh. They shuffle the cards and play again. They are happy.

Sara liked to collect shells on the beach. She had a big bucket full of them. She liked to look at their colors and shapes. She wanted to make a necklace for her mom.
One day, she saw a boy on the beach. He was wearing a crown and a cape. He looked sad. Sara walked up to him and said, "Hi, I'm Sara. What's your name?"
The boy looked up and said, "I'm Leo. I'm a prince. I'm lost. I can't find my castle."
Sara felt sorry for him. She said, "Don't be scared. I'll help you find your castle. Maybe it's over there." She pointed to a big sandcastle that some other kids had built.
Leo smiled and said, "Thank you, Sara. You're very kind. Can I see your shells? They're very pretty."
Sara nodded and said, "Sure. You can see them. You can even have one if you want. They're my collection."
Leo picked a shiny blue shell and said, "This one is my favorite. Can I have it?"
Sara said, "Yes, you can have it. It's a gift for you. Maybe it will bring you luck."
Leo put the shell in his pocket and said, "Thank you, Sara. You're my friend. Come on, let's go to the sandcastle. Maybe we can find some more shells on the way."
Sara and Leo held hands and walked to the sandcastle. They had fun playing and collecting shells. They forgot that they were lost. They were happy.

Sara likes to play catch with her big brother Tom. They use a soft ball that does not hurt. They throw the ball to each other and try to catch it. Sometimes they miss and the ball bounces on the floor or the wall.
One day, they were playing catch in the living room. They were careful not to hit the furniture. The furniture is big and hard and has things on it. Mom and Dad do not like it when they break things. They want the furniture to stay normal.
But then, Tom threw the ball too hard and too high. Sara jumped to catch it, but she could not reach it. The ball flew over her head and hit the lamp on the table. The lamp fell down and broke. The glass made a loud noise and a mess.
Mom and Dad heard the noise and came to see what happened. They were not happy. They told Tom and Sara to stop playing catch in the living room. They said it was not safe or smart. They said they had to clean up the mess and fix the lamp. They said they had to play catch outside or in their room.
Tom and Sara felt sorry. They said they were sorry. They helped Mom and Dad clean up the glass and the lamp. They learned their lesson. They did not play catch in the living room again. They played catch outside or in their room. They had fun, but they were more careful. They did not want to break any more furniture or make Mom and Dad mad. They wanted everything to be normal.

Tim and Mia were best friends. They liked to play outside in the park. One day, they saw a big kite in the sky. It was red and yellow and had a long tail.
"Wow, look at the kite!" Tim said. "It is so pretty and high!"
"Let's follow it!" Mia said. "Maybe we can find who is flying it!"
They ran after the kite, holding hands. They crossed the grass, the bridge, and the hill. They did not see anyone with a string or a stick.
"Where is the kite going?" Tim asked. "It is moving very fast!"
"Maybe it is free!" Mia said. "Maybe it does not need anyone to fly it!"
They followed the kite until they reached a big tree. The kite got stuck on a branch. It could not fly anymore.
"Oh no, the kite is trapped!" Tim said. "We have to help it!"
They looked for a way to climb the tree. But the tree was too tall and the branch was too far. They could not reach the kite.
"Maybe we can ask someone for help!" Mia said. "Maybe someone has a ladder or a stick!"
They looked around, but they did not see anyone. They felt sad and sorry for the kite.
"Hello, children!" a voice said. "Do you need some help?"
They turned around and saw an old man. He had a kind face and a humble smile. He was holding a long stick.
"Are you the one who is flying the kite?" Tim asked.
"No, I am not," the old man said. "But I saw you following it. It is a very nice kite. Do you want to get it down?"
"Yes, please!" Mia said. "We want to free the kite!"
The old man nodded. He walked to the tree and used his stick to poke the kite. The kite came loose and fell to the ground. Tim and Mia ran to pick it up.
"Thank you, thank you!" they said to the old man. "You are very kind and helpful!"
The old man smiled. "You are very welcome," he said. "You are very brave and curious. You can keep the kite if you want. Maybe it will fly again with you."
Tim and Mia hugged the old man. They thanked him again. They held the kite and waved goodbye. They ran back to the park, happy and excited. They decided to share the kite and fly it together. They had a new friend and a new adventure.

Lily and Tom are friends. They like to play hide and seek in the park. Lily is good at hiding. She can hide behind trees, under benches, and in bushes. Tom is good at seeking. He can run fast, look around, and listen for sounds.
One day, they play hide and seek again. Lily says, "I will hide, you will seek. Count to ten and then come find me." Tom says, "OK, I will count. One, two, three..." Lily runs away and looks for a good hiding spot. She sees a big box near the slide. She thinks, "This is a good hiding spot. Tom will not find me here." She goes inside the box and closes the lid.
Tom counts to ten and then says, "Ready or not, here I come!" He runs around the park and looks for Lily. He checks behind trees, under benches, and in bushes. He does not see Lily. He thinks, "Where is Lily? She is very good at hiding. Maybe she is near the slide." He goes to the slide and sees the big box. He thinks, "Maybe Lily is in the box. I will open the lid and see." He goes to the box and opens the lid.
Lily hears the lid open and says, "Boo!" She jumps out of the box and scares Tom. Tom is surprised and says, "Wow, you scared me! You are very good at hiding. You have a smart heart." Lily smiles and says, "Thank you. You are very good at seeking. You have a fast heart." They hug and say, "We are good friends. We have open hearts." They laugh and play some more.

Mom smiles and hugs Sara. She takes the bracelet and puts it on her wrist. "I love it, Sara. It is very beautiful. Thank you so much. You are very good at doing crafts."
Sara beams and hugs her mom back. She feels proud and happy. She likes to do nice things for her mom. She thinks her mom is the best.

Lily liked to look at photos of her family. She had a big book with many photos. Some photos were old and some were new. The old photos were black and white. The new photos were colorful. Lily liked the colorful photos more. They looked modern and happy.
One day, Lily wanted to show her photos to her friend Tom. She took the big book and went to Tom's house. Tom was happy to see Lily and the book. They sat on the floor and opened the book. They saw photos of Lily's mom and dad, her brother and sister, her grandparents and cousins. They saw photos of birthdays, holidays, trips and fun times.
But when they turned the page, they saw something bad. The photos were wet and sticky. Lily was sad and angry. She remembered that yesterday she left the book on the table. She also remembered that her brother spilled his juice on the table. He did not tell anyone. He did not dry the table. He did not dry the book. He ruined the photos.
Lily cried and Tom tried to comfort her. He said they could try to dry the photos with a hairdryer. He said they could try to make new photos with his camera. He said they could try to make the book look modern and happy again. Lily liked Tom's ideas. She stopped crying and smiled. She thanked Tom for being a good friend. They went to find a hairdryer and a camera. They hoped the photos would be okay.

Tom and Sue like to play in the garden. They dig in the dirt and look for bugs. One day, they find a long, slimy worm. Tom picks it up and shows it to Sue.
"Look, Sue, a worm!" Tom says.
Sue looks at the worm and makes a face. She does not like worms. She thinks they are yucky.
"Put it down, Tom. It is yucky," Sue says.
Tom does not think the worm is yucky. He thinks it is cool. He has a question for the worm.
"Hello, worm. How are you?" Tom asks.
The worm does not answer. It wiggles in Tom's hand. Tom thinks the worm is shy.
"Don't be shy, worm. I am Tom. This is Sue. We are your friends," Tom says.
Sue shakes her head. She does not want to be friends with the worm. She wants to play with something else.
"Tom, let's go play with the ball. The ball is fun. The worm is not fun," Sue says.
Tom looks at the ball. He likes the ball. But he also likes the worm. He does not want to leave the worm alone.
"Can we play with the ball and the worm?" Tom asks.
Sue sighs. She does not like Tom's idea. But she does not want to make Tom sad.
"Okay, Tom. We can play with the ball and the worm. But you have to hold the worm. I don't want to touch it," Sue says.
Tom smiles. He is happy. He holds the worm and the ball. He runs to the grass with Sue. They play with the ball and the worm. Tom thinks the worm likes to play too. He talks to the worm and asks it more questions. Sue thinks Tom is silly. But she plays with him anyway. She likes Tom. He is her friend.

Tim and Lily were twins who liked to play in the garden. They had a big pumpkin patch where they grew many pumpkins for Halloween. They were very proud of their pumpkins and took good care of them.
One day, they saw a big hole in the fence. They wondered who made the hole and what they wanted. They went to check their pumpkin patch and saw a terrible sight. Some of their pumpkins were gone and some were broken and rotting. They felt very sad and angry.
"Who did this to our pumpkins?" Tim asked.
"I don't know, but they are very mean and bad," Lily said.
They heard a loud snort and saw a big pig in their pumpkin patch. The pig had a dirty snout and muddy hooves. It was eating their pumpkins and making a mess.
"Hey, you! Stop that! Go away!" Tim shouted.
The pig looked at them and grunted. It did not care about their pumpkins or their feelings. It just wanted to eat and have fun.
Tim and Lily ran to the house and told their mom what happened. Their mom was very sorry and hugged them. She said they could fix the fence and plant new seeds. She also said they could go to the market and buy some pumpkins for Halloween.
Tim and Lily felt a little better. They still loved their pumpkin patch and hoped the pig would not come back. They learned to be careful and watch out for their pumpkins. They also learned to share and help each other. They had a happy Halloween and carved some funny faces on their pumpkins.

Tom and Mia are friends. They like to play in the park. They have a red ball. They kick the ball to each other. They have fun.
But one day, a big boy comes. He is mean. He takes the ball from Tom and Mia. He says, "This is my ball now. Go away." He runs away with the ball.
Tom and Mia are sad. They want their ball back. They sit on a bench. They do not know what to do.
Then, they see a girl. She is nice. She has a bike. She sees Tom and Mia. She asks, "Why are you sad?"
Tom and Mia tell her what happened. The girl says, "That is not fair. I can help you. I know where the big boy lives. He is my brother. He is always mean. Come with me. We can get your ball back."
Tom and Mia are happy. They think the girl is helpful. They believe her. They get on the bike with her. They go to the big boy's house. They find the ball. They take it back. They say, "Thank you" to the girl. They go back to the park. They play with the ball. They have fun.

Anna and Ben are friends. They like to play together. One day, they go to the park. They see a big tree with many leaves. They want to climb the tree.
"Can we climb the tree?" Anna asks Ben.
"Yes, we can. But we have to be careful. The tree is very high." Ben says.
They start to climb the tree. They hold on to the branches. They have fun. They see many birds and squirrels. They feel happy.
Anna has a bow in her hair. It is red and shiny. She likes her bow. She puts it in her pocket. She does not want to lose it.
Ben has a map in his pocket. It is old and dirty. He found it in his grandpa's attic. He thinks it is a treasure map. He wants to follow it.
They reach the top of the tree. They look around. They see a big hill. Ben takes out his map. He points to the hill.
"Look, Anna. The map says there is a treasure on the hill. Let's go and find it." Ben says.
"OK, Ben. But we have to go down the tree first. And we have to be organized. We have to remember where we put our things." Anna says.
They start to go down the tree. They are not careful. They are in a hurry. They forget to take their things. Anna forgets her bow. Ben forgets his map.
They reach the ground. They run to the hill. They do not look back. They do not see a big dog. The dog sees them. The dog is hungry. The dog smells their things. The dog goes to the tree. The dog finds their things. The dog eats their things. The dog is happy.
Anna and Ben reach the hill. They look for the treasure. They do not find anything. They are sad. They want to go back. They go back to the tree. They look for their things. They do not find anything. They see the dog. The dog has their things in his mouth. The dog growls at them. They are scared. They cry.
The moral of the story is: Be careful and organized when you play. Do not forget your things. Or a dog might eat them.

Tom and Lily are friends. They like to play with toys and books. One day, they go to the library with their moms. There are many books in the library. Tom sees a big book with many words and pictures. He wants the book. He thinks, "This book is mine. I will take it home."
He does not ask his mom or the librarian. He puts the book in his bag. He steals the book. He is happy. He thinks, "No one will know. I have the best book."
Lily sees Tom with the book. She likes the book too. She thinks, "This book is nice. I want to see it." She asks Tom, "Can I look at your book?" Tom says, "No. This is my book. Go away." He is mean. He is rough.
Lily is sad. She thinks, "Tom is not a good friend. He does not share. He is selfish." She tells her mom, "Tom has a book from the library. He did not borrow it. He stole it." Her mom is shocked. She says, "That is very bad. He should not steal. He should return the book and say sorry."
She tells Tom's mom, "Tom has a book from the library. He did not borrow it. He stole it." Tom's mom is angry. She says, "Tom, is that true? Did you steal the book?" Tom is scared. He says, "Yes. I stole the book. I wanted it. I did not think." He is ashamed.
Tom's mom says, "You have to give back the book and apologize to the librarian. You have to learn your lesson. Stealing is wrong. It hurts others and yourself. You have to be honest and kind." She takes Tom to the library. Tom gives back the book and says sorry. He is sorry.
The librarian is glad. She says, "Thank you for returning the book and saying sorry. I forgive you. But you have to be careful. Stealing is a bad habit. It can get you in trouble. You have to respect the rules and the rights of others. You have to ask before you take something. You have to share and be generous." She gives Tom a hug. She is nice.
Tom feels better. He says, "I understand. I will not steal again. I will be good. I will be a better friend." He looks at Lily. He says, "Lily, I am sorry for being mean and rough. I was wrong. Can you forgive me? Can we be friends again?" Lily smiles. She says, "Yes, I forgive you. Yes, we can be friends again. But you have to share your books with me." Tom nods. He says, "Yes, I will share my books with you. And you can share your books with me." They hug. They are happy.
The end.

Anna and Ben like to pretend. They have a big box of toys and clothes. They can be anything they want. Today, they want to be cowboys and cowgirls. They put on hats and boots and belts. They find a rope and a stick.
Anna and Ben go outside. They see a big tree. They say it is their ranch. They tie the rope to the tree. They say it is their lasso. They take the stick. They say it is their horse. They hop on the stick and make horse sounds. They run around the tree and pretend to catch cows.
But then, they hear a loud noise. It is a dog. It is barking and running towards them. Anna and Ben are scared. They think the dog is a wolf. They drop the stick and the rope. They run back to the house. They slam the door and lock it.
They hug each other and breathe hard. They are safe. They are not cowboys and cowgirls anymore. They are just Anna and Ben. They laugh and say it was a fun game. They say they will play again tomorrow. But they will find a different place to pretend. A place with no dogs.

Sara and Ben are twins. They like to play with their toys. One day, they find a big box of cards. The cards have pictures of animals, fruits, and shapes.
"Let's play a game," Sara says. "We can match the cards that are the same."
"OK," Ben says. "I will go first."
Ben picks a card. It has a picture of a banana. He looks for another card with a banana. He finds one and puts them together.
"Good job, Ben," Sara says. "Now it's my turn."
Sara picks a card. It has a picture of a palm. She knows what a palm is. It is a part of her hand. She shows Ben her palm.
"Look, Ben, this is a palm," Sara says.
"I know, Sara, I have a palm too," Ben says. He shows Sara his palm.
They compare their palms. They are the same size and shape. They have five fingers each. They have lines and curves on their skin.
"Our palms match," Sara says. "They are the same."
"Yes, they do," Ben says. "But they are not ordinary. They are special."
"Why are they special?" Sara asks.
"Because they are ours," Ben says. "And we are twins. We are the best match of all."
Sara smiles. She hugs Ben. They are happy. They love each other. They love their palms. They love their game.

Anna and Ben are friends. They like to play with toys and share them. One day, they find a big box of toys in the park. They are very happy and run to the box.
"Look, Anna, a doll!" Ben says. He picks up the doll and hugs it.
"Look, Ben, a car!" Anna says. She picks up the car and rolls it on the ground.
They play with the doll and the car for a long time. They forget about the other toys in the box.
A mean boy sees them. He wants the doll and the car. He sneaks up to the box and takes all the other toys. He puts them in his bag and runs away.
Anna and Ben do not see him. They keep playing with the doll and the car.
Soon, they get tired and hungry. They decide to go home. They put the doll and the car back in the box. They are surprised to see the box is empty.
"Where are the other toys?" Anna asks.
"I don't know. Maybe someone took them." Ben says.
They are sad and angry. They suffer because they have no more toys to play with.
They look around and see the mean boy. He is laughing and holding his bag of toys. He sees them and sticks out his tongue.
"Ha ha, I have all your toys. You have nothing. You are losers." He says.
Anna and Ben are very mad. They run to the mean boy and try to get their toys back. They pull and push and shout.
"Give us our toys. They are ours. You are mean." They say.
The mean boy does not want to give them their toys. He holds his bag tight and kicks and hits them.
"Go away. They are mine. You are stupid." He says.
They fight for a long time. They hurt each other. They suffer because they have pain.
A nice lady sees them. She is walking her dog. She hears the noise and comes to see what is wrong. She sees the mean boy, the empty box, and the bag of toys. She sees Anna and Ben, their hands are red and their faces are wet.
"What is going on here? Why are you fighting?" She asks.
Anna and Ben tell her what happened. They show her the doll and the car. They say they are their toys and the mean boy took them.
The nice lady looks at the mean boy. She is not happy. She scolds him and makes him give back the toys. She says he is bad and he should say sorry.
The mean boy is scared. He does not want to say sorry. He cries and runs away.
The nice lady gives Anna and Ben the toys. She says they are good and they should share them. She says she is sorry they suffer and she gives them a hug.
Anna and Ben are happy. They thank the nice lady and her dog. They say they are sorry they fight and they hug each other.
They take the toys and go home. They play with them and share them. They do not suffer anymore. They are friends.

Tim and Sam were friends. They liked to play with toys. One day, they found a big box. Inside the box, there was an elephant. The elephant was small and gray. It had a long nose and big ears.
"Wow, look at this!" Tim said. He picked up the elephant and hugged it. "It is so soft and cute. I want to keep it."
"No, I want it!" Sam said. He grabbed the elephant from Tim and pulled it. "It is mine. I saw it first."
Tim and Sam started to fight. They both wanted the elephant. They did not want to share. The elephant did not like that. It felt scared and sad. It used its long nose to make a loud noise. "Prrrrr!"
Tim and Sam stopped fighting. They looked at the elephant. The elephant looked at them. It frowned. It did not want to be in the box. It wanted to be free and happy.
"Sorry, elephant," Tim said. He felt bad. He let go of the elephant.
"Sorry, elephant," Sam said. He felt bad too. He also let go of the elephant.
The elephant smiled. It was glad. It used its long nose to touch Tim and Sam. It thanked them. Then it walked out of the box. It wanted to find its family.
Tim and Sam watched the elephant go. They felt sorry for the elephant. They also felt sorry for each other.
"Can we still be friends?" Tim asked.
"Of course we can," Sam said. He hugged Tim. "Friends share and care."
They smiled. They learned a lesson. They decided to play with other toys. They did not fight anymore. They were happy.

Tom and Lily like to play in the park. They like to slide, swing and run. One day, they see a big pole in the grass. They wonder what it is for.
They run to the pole and touch it. It is cold and hard. They try to climb it, but it is too slippery. They try to push it, but it is too heavy. They try to pull it, but it is too stuck. They are puzzled.
They hear a loud noise. They look up and see a big truck. The truck has a sign that says "Hot Dogs". The truck stops near the pole. A man gets out of the truck. He smiles and says "Hello, kids. Do you want a hot dog?"
Tom and Lily nod. They like hot dogs. The man gives them each a hot dog on a bun. He also gives them some sauce. He says "This sauce is spicy. It makes your mouth hot. Do you like spicy sauce?"
Tom and Lily say "Yes". They put some sauce on their hot dogs. They take a big bite. They feel the sauce in their mouth. It is spicy. It makes their mouth hot. They like it. They say "Yum".
They thank the man. The man says "You're welcome. Enjoy your hot dogs. Do you know what this pole is for?" He points to the pole.
Tom and Lily shake their head. They do not know. The man says "This pole is for my truck. It is a power pole. It gives electricity to my truck. It makes my hot dogs hot. Do you understand?"
Tom and Lily nod. They understand. They think the pole is cool. They say "Wow". They finish their hot dogs. They say goodbye to the man. They run back to the slide, the swing and the run. They are happy. They have fun. They have learned something new. They have found a pole and a spicy sauce.

Tom and Mia are friends. They like to play in the park. One day, they see a big slide. They want to try it.
"Let's go up the slide!" Tom says.
"OK!" Mia says.
They run to the slide. Tom goes first. He climbs the steps. He sits on the slide. He slides down. He laughs.
"Your turn, Mia!" he says.
Mia follows Tom. She climbs the steps. She sits on the slide. But she is scared. She does not slide down. She holds on to the slide.
"Come on, Mia!" Tom says. "It is easy and fun!"
"I don't want to!" Mia says. "It is too high and fast!"
Mia struggles to get off the slide. She tries to go back up the steps. But she slips. She slides down. She screams.
Tom catches her. He hugs her.
"It's OK, Mia!" he says. "You did it! You are brave!"
Mia stops screaming. She looks at Tom. She smiles.
"Thank you, Tom!" she says. "You are a good friend!"
They hug. They are happy. They land on the grass. They play some more.

Ben and Lily liked to play on the beach. They liked to dig in the sand and find shells and rocks. One day, they saw a big pile of oysters. They were shiny and smooth and had funny shapes.
"Let's count them!" Ben said. He liked to count things. He picked up an oyster and said, "One." Lily picked up another one and said, "Two." They kept counting until they had ten oysters in their hands.
"Let's open them and see what's inside!" Lily said. She liked to explore things. She used a rock to hit an oyster and crack it open. She saw a slimy thing and a shiny thing. "Look, a pearl!" she said. She took out the shiny thing and put it in her pocket.
Ben wanted to find a pearl too. He hit an oyster with a rock, but it was hard to open. He hit it harder and harder, but it did not crack. He got angry and threw the oyster at the pile. The oyster hit another oyster and made a loud noise. The noise scared a big seagull that was sitting on the pile. The seagull flew away and dropped a messy thing on Ben's head.
"Yuck!" Ben said. He felt the messy thing on his hair and face. It was sticky and smelly. He started to cry. Lily laughed and said, "That's what you get for being mean to the oysters!" She ran away with her pearl. Ben was left alone on the beach, with a messy head and no pearls. He wished he had not tried to open the oysters. He wished he had just counted them.
<|endoftext|>

Lily and Ben were playing with their toy cars in the backyard. They liked to zoom them on the grass and make loud noises. Lily had a red car and Ben had a blue car. They pretended they were racing each other.
"Zoom, zoom, zoom! I'm faster than you!" Lily said.
"No, you're not! I'm faster than you!" Ben said.
They zoomed their cars until they reached the fence. There was a big hole in the fence. They saw a black cat on the other side. The cat looked dirty and sad. It had oil on its fur.
"Look, a cat!" Lily said.
"Let's go see it!" Ben said.
They crawled through the hole and went to the cat. The cat was scared and hissed at them. It tried to run away, but it was stuck in the oil.
"Don't be afraid, cat. We want to help you," Lily said.
She reached out her hand to touch the cat. The cat scratched her hand and made her cry.
"Ow, ow, ow! The cat hurt me!" Lily said.
Ben saw that Lily was hurt. He felt sorry for her. He also felt sorry for the cat. He was brave and decided to try again.
"Shh, shh, shh. It's okay, cat. We're not bad. We have water and soap. We can clean you," Ben said.
He spoke softly and gently to the cat. He moved slowly and carefully to the cat. He picked up the cat and held it in his arms. The cat stopped hissing and started to purr.
"Good job, Ben! You're so brave!" Lily said.
She smiled and wiped her tears. She got some water and soap from the house. She helped Ben wash the oil off the cat. The cat looked happy and clean.
"Thank you, kids. You're very kind," the cat said.
The cat licked their faces and cuddled with them. They became friends.
The moral of the story is: Be brave and kind to animals, even if they are scared and hurt. They will appreciate your help and love.
<|endoftext|>

Tom and Lily were hungry. They wanted to eat some beef for lunch. But their mom was not at home. She went to work at the farm. She said she would be back soon.
Tom and Lily looked for some beef in the kitchen. They saw a big pot on the stove. They smelled something good. They thought it was beef. They wanted to open the pot and see.
But the pot had a lock on it. They did not know how to unlock it. They tried to pull and twist the lock. But it did not move. They felt sad and angry.
They heard a knock on the door. They ran to the door and opened it. It was their dad. He came back from the market. He had a bag of food in his hand.
"Dad, dad, we are hungry. We want to eat some beef. But the pot has a lock on it. We can't open it. Can you help us?" Tom and Lily said.
Dad smiled and hugged them. He said, "I'm sorry, my dear. The pot does not have beef in it. It has beans. Mom cooked them for dinner. She locked the pot to keep them warm. She left a note for me. She said we can eat some bread and cheese for lunch. And some fruit and milk. Do you like that?"
Tom and Lily nodded. They felt a little disappointed. But they were glad to see their dad. They knew their mom worked hard at the farm. They knew they were poor. But they loved their family. They followed their dad to the table. They ate some bread and cheese. And some fruit and milk. They thanked their dad for the food. They waited for their mom to come back. They hoped she would bring some beef for them.
<|endoftext|>

Sara and Ben like to play in the creek. They splash and run and look for fish. Sometimes they find frogs and snails and rocks. They have fun in the water.
One day, they see a big mud puddle near the creek. They want to jump in it and get dirty. They run to the puddle and jump and laugh. They make mud pies and mud balls and mud hats. They are very dirty.
Mom sees them and says, "Oh no! You are all muddy! You need to wipe off the mud and take a bath!" She gives them a towel and tells them to wipe their faces and hands and feet. They try to wipe off the mud, but it is sticky and hard. They still have mud on them.
Mom says, "Come on, let's go to the creek and wash off the mud. The creek is nice and clean and cool." She takes them to the creek and helps them wash off the mud. They feel the water on their skin and hair. They see the fish and frogs and snails and rocks. They say, "Thank you, Mom. The creek is nice."
Mom says, "You're welcome, Sara and Ben. I'm glad you had fun in the creek. But next time, please stay away from the mud puddle. It is not nice." They nod and hug Mom. They are happy and clean.
<|endoftext|>

Tom liked to go to the barber with his dad. The barber had a cool chair that went up and down, and a big mirror, and a lot of scissors and combs. Tom liked to watch the barber cut his dad's hair and make him look neat.
One day, Tom wanted to be like the barber. He found some scissors and a comb in his mom's drawer, and he sneaked into his sister's room. His sister was sleeping on her bed, with her long hair spread on the pillow. Tom thought he could give her a nice haircut, like the barber did for his dad.
He took the scissors and the comb, and started to cut his sister's hair. He cut it very short, and made it look funny. He did not know how to use the scissors and the comb well, and he hurt his sister's head. His sister woke up and screamed. She saw her hair on the floor, and on Tom's hands. She was very angry and sad.
Mom and dad heard the scream, and ran to the room. They saw what Tom had done, and they were very shocked and upset. They scolded Tom, and took him and his sister to the barber. The barber tried to fix his sister's hair, but he could not make it long again. He said it would take a long time to grow back. His sister cried, and Tom felt very sorry.
The moral of the story is: do not play with scissors and combs, and do not cut other people's hair. You could hurt them, and make them unhappy. Only the barber can cut hair, because he knows how to do it well. You should respect other people's things, and ask before you touch them.
<|endoftext|>

Tom was a little boy who liked to play with his toys. He had many toys, but his favorite was a red car. He liked to zoom the car around the floor and make loud noises. He also liked to put the car in his mouth and bite it.
One day, Tom was playing with his car in his room. He was having fun, but he was also tired. He did not want to stop playing, so he did not listen to his mom when she called him for dinner. He put the car in his mouth and lay down on his bed.
Soon, Tom fell asleep with the car in his mouth. He did not know that the car had a small wheel that could come off. While he was sleeping, the wheel came off and went into his throat. Tom started to choke and cough. He woke up and felt scared and hurt.
His mom heard him and ran to his room. She saw the car in his mouth and the wheel in his throat. She quickly took the car out of his mouth and helped him spit out the wheel. She hugged him and took him to the doctor.
The doctor checked Tom and said he was lucky. He said that the wheel could have hurt him more if it stayed in his throat. He told Tom not to put toys in his mouth, because they are not food. He said that toys are for playing, not for eating.
Tom learned his lesson. He said sorry to his mom and thanked the doctor. He promised not to put toys in his mouth again. He also promised to listen to his mom when she called him for dinner. He realized that playing is fun, but eating and sleeping are important too. He was a good boy after that.
<|endoftext|>

Tom and Mia were playing in the park. They liked to run, jump and slide on the grass and the swings. They saw a big tree with many leaves and branches. They wanted to see what was behind the tree.
They ran to the tree and looked behind it. They saw a big pile of sticks and stones. Some of the sticks were long and sharp. They looked like spears. Tom and Mia were curious. They wanted to touch the spears.
"Look, Mia, spears!" Tom said. He picked up one of the spears and held it in his hand. He felt the pointy end. It was hard and cold.
"Be careful, Tom, you might hurt yourself!" Mia said. She picked up another spear and looked at it. She saw some marks and drawings on the wood. They looked like animals and people.
"Wow, Mia, look at these!" Tom said. He saw the same marks and drawings on his spear. He wondered who made them and why.
"Maybe they are very old, Tom. Maybe someone left them here a long time ago." Mia said. She wanted to know more about the spears and the marks.
They decided to take the spears with them and show them to their mom and dad. They thought they had made a big discovery. They were very happy and excited.
They ran back to the grass and the swings. They saw their mom and dad sitting on a bench. They waved at them and shouted.
"Mom, dad, look what we found!" Tom and Mia said. They held up the spears and showed them to their mom and dad.
Their mom and dad looked surprised and worried. They got up from the bench and walked to Tom and Mia. They took the spears from their hands and looked at them closely.
"Where did you get these, Tom and Mia?" Their mom asked. She sounded serious and scared.
"Behind the big tree, mom. There was a pile of sticks and stones. Some of the sticks were spears. They have marks and drawings on them. We wanted to show you. We made a discovery!" Tom and Mia said. They smiled and hoped their mom and dad would be proud of them.
Their mom and dad looked at each other and frowned. They did not smile. They did not look proud. They looked angry and sad.
"Tom and Mia, these are not spears. These are arrows. They are very dangerous. They can hurt people and animals. They are not for playing. They are for fighting. Someone left them here because they were in a war. A war is when people are very mad and mean to each other. A war is very bad and sad. You should not touch these arrows. You should not take them with you. You should leave them where they are. Do you understand?" Their dad said. He sounded stern and loud.
Tom and Mia felt confused and scared. They did not understand what a war was. They did not understand why the arrows were bad and sad. They did not understand why their mom and dad were angry and sad. They did not like the arrows anymore. They felt a bitter taste in their mouths.
"Yes, dad, we understand. We are sorry, dad. We did not know, dad." Tom and Mia said. They nodded and looked down.
Their mom and dad hugged them and kissed them. They told them they loved them and they were not mad at them. They told them they were brave and smart and they did make a discovery. They told them they would explain more about the arrows and the war when they got home. They told them they would find something else to play with in the park.
Tom and Mia felt a little better. They still felt bitter, but they also felt loved. They hugged and kissed their mom and dad back. They said they loved them too. They said they were sorry again. They said they wanted to play something else.
Their mom and dad smiled and nodded. They took the arrows and put them back behind the tree. They told Tom and Mia to stay away from them. They took their hands and walked with them to the grass and the swings. They helped them find a ball and a kite. They played with them and laughed with them. They had fun in the park. They forgot about the arrows and the war. They were happy again.
<|endoftext|>

Ben and Lily were twins who liked to play pretend. One night, they decided to be astronauts and go to the moon. They put on their helmets and suits and got into their cardboard rocket.
"Ready for blast off?" Ben asked.
"Ready!" Lily said.
They counted down from ten and made loud noises as they flew into the sky. They looked out the window and saw the moon shining bright.
"Wow, it's so big and round!" Lily said.
"Let's land and explore!" Ben said.
They pretended to land on the moon and got out of their rocket. They jumped and bounced on the ground.
"This is fun!" Ben said.
They saw some rocks and dust and picked them up.
"Look, I found a moon rock!" Lily said.
"Me too!" Ben said.
They put them in their pockets and looked for more.
"Hey, what's that?" Ben said, pointing to a big crater.
"Let's go see!" Lily said.
They ran to the crater and looked inside. They saw a small creature with green fur and big eyes. It looked scared and hungry.
"Hello, who are you?" Lily asked.
"I'm Mimi, I live here," the creature said.
"What do you eat?" Ben asked.
"I eat cheese, but I can't find any," Mimi said.
"Cheese? On the moon?" Lily asked.
"Yes, the moon is made of cheese, but it's very tough and hard to get," Mimi said.
"Maybe we can help you," Ben said.
He took out a knife and a plate from his rocket and cut a piece of cheese from the moon. He put it on the plate and gave it to Mimi.
"Here, try this," he said.
Mimi took a bite and smiled.
"Mmm, this is good, thank you!" Mimi said.
"You're welcome," Ben said.
Lily took out a cup and a bottle of water from her rocket and poured some water into the cup. She gave it to Mimi.
"Here, drink this," she said.
Mimi drank the water and sighed.
"Ah, this is refreshing, thank you!" Mimi said.
"You're welcome," Lily said.
Ben and Lily smiled and sat with Mimi. They talked and played and became friends.
"We're glad we met you, Mimi," Ben said.
"Me too, you're very nice," Mimi said.
They looked at the stars and the earth and enjoyed the night.
The end.
<|endoftext|>

One day, Tom and his mom went to a big place to buy some things. Tom liked the place, because it had many toys and books and colors. He wanted to buy everything, but his mom said no. She said they only had some money, and they needed to buy food and clothes and other things.
Tom saw a big red ball that he liked very much. He asked his mom if he could buy it. His mom said yes, but only if he was good and stayed with her. Tom was happy and hugged his mom. He took the ball and followed her.
But then, Tom saw something that made him very frightened. It was a big dog, with black fur and sharp teeth. It was barking and jumping and pulling on a rope. Tom was scared of dogs, because they were loud and mean. He dropped the ball and ran away from the dog. He did not see where he was going, and he got lost in the place.
He looked around and saw many people and things, but he did not see his mom. He felt alone and sad and scared. He started to cry and call for his mom. He wished he had his ball, because it was soft and nice.
Then, he heard a voice that he knew. It was his mom. She was looking for him and calling his name. She saw him and ran to him. She hugged him and kissed him and said she was sorry. She said she was worried and angry, because he ran away from her. She said he should never do that again, because it was dangerous and bad.
Tom said he was sorry too. He said he was frightened of the dog, and he wanted his ball. His mom said she understood, but he should always stay with her, no matter what. She said she loved him and he was her good boy. She said she had his ball, and she would buy it for him. She said they would go home and play with it.
Tom was happy and relieved. He hugged his mom and said he loved her too. He said he was her good boy, and he would never run away from her again. He said he was not frightened of the dog anymore, because his mom was with him. He took his ball and smiled. He liked the place, but he liked his mom more.
<|endoftext|>

Lily and Sam went to the beach with Mom and Dad. They liked to play in the sand and splash in the water. They saw many things on the beach, like shells, rocks, and birds.
One day, they found a crab in the sand. It was small and red, and it had big claws. Lily wanted to touch it, but Sam was anxious. He said, "No, Lily, don't touch it! It might pinch you!"
Lily said, "But it looks so cute! I want to be its friend!" She reached out her hand to the crab, but the crab was scared. It snapped its claws at Lily and ran away.
Lily was sad. She said, "Why did it do that? I just wanted to say hello!"
Mom came over and hugged Lily. She said, "The crab was afraid of you, Lily. It doesn't know you. It thinks you might hurt it. That's why it tried to protect itself."
Lily said, "But I wouldn't hurt it, Mom. I just wanted to play with it."
Mom said, "I know, Lily, but the crab doesn't know that. Maybe next time, you can watch it from a distance and see how it lives. Maybe you can learn something from it."
Lily nodded. She said, "Okay, Mom. I will do that. Maybe the crab will like me if I don't bother it."
Mom smiled. She said, "Maybe it will, Lily. Maybe it will. Now, let's go and have some fun. Do you want to wear your sun hat?"
Lily said, "Yes, Mom. I want to wear my sun hat. It is pink and pretty. And I want to wear my sunglasses, too. They are cool and shiny."
Mom said, "Okay, Lily. You can wear your sun hat and your sunglasses. You look very nice. Now, let's go and join Sam. He is making a sand castle. Do you want to help him?"
Lily said, "Yes, Mom. I want to help Sam. Maybe we can make a sand crab, too. A friendly sand crab."
Mom said, "That sounds like a good idea, Lily. A friendly sand crab. Let's go and make one."
